newsitem.title: USA: Foxmoor may seek bankruptcy reorganization.
newsitem.headline: Foxmoor may seek bankruptcy reorganization.

text.p: Foxmoor Industries Ltd said Wednesday it is mulling its options, including possible reorganization under bankruptcy law.
The company said in a statement that its results for the quarters ended December 31 and March 31 may have overstated earnings and inaccurately reported its cash position.

It said that its cash position, which had been reported to be $1,112,000 in March, is less than $20,000, and that the collection of a substantial portion of its accounts receivable, assignments receivable and advances to contractors -- totalling nearly $2 million -- "appears to be doubtful."
It said its liabilities are about $771,000.
It said to prevent further decline in its financial position, it is closing its warehouse in Denver and winding down other operations.
"The company is considering all options for preservation of the company's assets, including the possibility of a reorganization under the bankruptcy laws," the statement said.
Additionally, the company said Ross Corace had resigned as its president and that chairman and chief executive Paul Eagland had been named to the vacancy.

"Based on its preliminary review, management believes that the former president of the company, Mr. Ross Corace, has financial obligations to the company in excess of $1,250,000," the statement said. It gave no further details and it was not immediately possible to reach the company for further comment.
The company said it would hire a new accounting firm to review its accounts and help determine the accuracy of its prior financial statements.
